questions.question: What is 'music sampling' in copyright terms?
options: Using a short portion of another's sound recording in a new song
Recording a live concert without permission
questions.explanation: Music sampling means reusing a portion of another artist’s sound recording in a new song, often leading to copyright disputes.

questions.question: Which two copyrights are involved in a song?
questions.explanation: A song has two separate copyrights — one in the musical composition (melody, lyrics) and another in the sound recording.

questions.question: The case 'Vanilla Ice vs. Queen & David Bowie' was about which song?
questions.explanation: 'Ice Ice Baby' by Vanilla Ice sampled 'Under Pressure' by Queen & David Bowie without permission, leading to a copyright dispute.

questions.question: What was the main issue in the 'Blurred Lines vs. Marvin Gaye' case?
options: Copying the 'feel' and style of a song
Using the same music video concept
questions.explanation: The Blurred Lines case centered on whether copying the 'feel' or 'vibe' of Marvin Gaye’s song constituted infringement.

questions.question: What does 'de minimis' mean in copyright law?
options: Too trivial or minor to be considered infringement
questions.explanation: The 'de minimis' principle means the copied portion is so small or insignificant that it doesn’t amount to infringement.

questions.question: Which artist was accused of copying Marvin Gaye’s song 'Got to Give It Up'?
questions.explanation: Pharrell Williams and Robin Thicke were sued for 'Blurred Lines', alleged to have copied 'Got to Give It Up' by Marvin Gaye.

questions.question: Why is music sampling often legally risky?
options: Because both composition and recording rights may need clearance
questions.explanation: Sampling requires permission from both composition and sound recording owners; missing either can lead to infringement.

questions.question: What is a 'sample clearance'?
options: A license obtained to legally use a music sample
A legal fine for copying music
questions.explanation: Sample clearance is the permission granted by copyright owners to use parts of their music in another track.

questions.question: Which of the following cases introduced the concept of 'sound-alike' infringement?
questions.explanation: The 'Blurred Lines' case expanded the scope of infringement to include copying a song's 'feel' or 'sound-alike' quality.

questions.question: Under copyright law, can a very short musical phrase be protected?
options: Yes, if it’s distinctive and original
No, short phrases are always free to use
Only if sung by the original artist
questions.explanation: Even short musical phrases can be protected if they’re sufficiently original and recognizable.

questions.question: What was the outcome of the 'Blurred Lines' lawsuit?
options: Thicke and Williams were found liable and paid damages
Marvin Gaye’s family lost the case
It was ruled as fair use
questions.explanation: The court found 'Blurred Lines' infringed Marvin Gaye’s song, awarding over $5 million to Gaye’s estate.

questions.question: In India, what determines if sampling is 'substantial enough' to be infringement?
questions.explanation: Courts look at the qualitative importance of the copied part, not just how long it is.

questions.question: The 'de minimis' rule may NOT apply when:
options: The copied part is the most recognizable hook
Only one second of audio is used
questions.explanation: Even a small copied portion can infringe if it’s the most identifiable or important part of the work.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the purpose of the 'de minimis' rule?
options: To avoid punishing trivial uses that cause no harm
questions.explanation: The 'de minimis' rule prevents overreach by exempting negligible copying that doesn’t harm the copyright owner.

questions.question: Can a remix be considered an infringement?
options: Yes, if original samples are used without permission
questions.explanation: Remixes using original sound recordings or melodies without permission can infringe copyright.

questions.question: What is the legal test often used to determine infringement in music cases?
questions.explanation: Courts apply the 'substantial similarity' test to check if an average listener would recognize copied elements.

questions.question: What is one key difference between 'sampling' and 'covering' a song?
options: Sampling uses the original recording, covering recreates it
Sampling is legal, covering is not
questions.explanation: Sampling uses parts of an existing recording, while covering means recording your own version of a composition.

questions.question: If an artist samples a 2-second drum beat, what should they do to stay safe legally?
options: Get sample clearance from copyright owners
questions.explanation: Even short samples can require clearance. Modifying or shortening doesn’t automatically make it legal.

questions.question: Which of these best defines 'sampling wars'?
options: A series of lawsuits over the legality of music sampling
questions.explanation: 'Sampling wars' refers to the numerous legal battles between artists over the unauthorized use of samples.

questions.question: Which famous Indian case dealt with unlicensed use of background tracks?
options: Gramophone Co. of India vs. Super Cassettes
questions.explanation: The Gramophone Co. of India vs. Super Cassettes case highlighted unlicensed reuse of music recordings in India.

questions.question: If a sample is licensed, what must the new artist usually do?
options: Pay a fee and give credit
questions.explanation: Sample licenses often require both payment and proper credit to the original creators.

questions.question: What happens if an artist ignores a DMCA takedown notice?
options: The platform may remove or block their content
questions.explanation: Ignoring a DMCA notice can lead to removal or account strikes by the platform.

questions.question: What is one defense artists often use in sampling cases?
questions.explanation: Artists often argue that the sampled portion was too trivial ('de minimis') to count as infringement.

questions.question: What is the best way for artists to avoid sampling disputes?
options: Credit the artist in album notes
questions.explanation: Legal clearance and documentation are the safest methods to avoid copyright disputes.

questions.question: Why are sampling cases significant in copyright education?
options: They demonstrate real-world applications of copyright principles
They always lead to new music genres
They show copyright doesn’t apply to sound
questions.explanation: Sampling cases illustrate how copyright law balances creativity with ownership rights in practical, high-profile ways.
